text:
Nice deep brown coloured body with a large, off-white head, about four centimetres tall. Aroma of roasted malt, nuts, earth and a good dose of caramel sweetness from pure sugars. Medium-bodied; Assertive nutty and earthy flavour from the malt with a touch of sugar, some light mushroom and musty flavours and some subdued chocolate flavours. Aftertaste is fairly minimal with just malt and a little sweetness and mostly toasted malt flavours, all with a relatively thin body. Overall, a decent beer, but not showing much complexity, or depth in flavours - just the malt and sugars and not much else. Still, nice to try, and im sure the age helped mute the flavours to some degree. I sampled this 75 cL bottle purchased from Super Market Liqours in Fort Collins, Colorado on 17-March-2016 for US$6,99 sampled at Shenandoah National Park on 14-May-2016. 

Bottled: 31-July-2014 // Purchased: 17-March-2016 // Sampled: 14-May-2016

[Tap] Deep brown pour with a small amount of head on top. Aromas of peat, light smoke, earthy hops and some cocoa powder. Flavors of toffee, molasses, peat, wood smoke, earthy notes and grains. Decent balance. Gets kind of boozy as it warms. Pretty good overall. Tasting notes from 9/2014.
On draft at the brewery. Pours a clear cola with a tan head. Light nutty nose. Flavors of caramel. Medium bodied. Slightly sweet malty finish

Cabbage and tobacco nose with boozy cherry accents. Clear brown, thin head. Tobacco is dominant, but earthy potato and cranberry notes are also present. Medium body, moderate carbonation. Too vegetal to me. Aside from that I thought it was neat and would like to try it in a fresher condition.

2014 vintage bomber.Rough pour into a thistle glass, yields a nice foamy billowing head, nutty, peaty aroma, very earthy . Taste brings in some malt sweetness, roast grains. Slick mouth feel , lingering sweetness.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and shaker served showing a darkest brown color, with good clarity to allow ruby highlighting to show through, a presentable layer of brownish tan head froth, and wavy cling to the lacing. The aroma was lightly roasted, with some sweetness, and touches of treacle, and dark fruit. Medium bodied and malty, with modest but suitable carbonation, the taste was similar to the nose, remained lightly roasted and moderately sweet, and further added defining notes of light peat smoke, toffee, and caramel, balanced by a moderate, earthy hop bitterness. A quite drinkable, hefty Scottish.

750ml bottle. Peaty, malty aroma with notes of caramel and dark fruit. Pours dark brown tinged in ruby with a thin tan head with some lacing. Starts with sweet caramel and dark fruit coming through nicely. Finishes smooth with a bit of dryness with wonderful smokey peat flavor. Nice scotch ale.

Red/brown color. Peat nose, musty, with grassy and vegetal notes--like being in the ground as theyre chopping peat from the hill. Not especially sweet in the scheme of things (esp. for the style). Smoke comes out again in the flavor, but murkily. (At Ale Jail Anniversary Party 2014)

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2014 On tap, poured into a shaker. Sweet cherry jolly rancher and raisin aromas come through with a slight cookie batter note. It pours a dark, opaque, brown-red with a soft, tan, gelatin head. Ample sheet lace is left on the glass and a medium-thick soft ring is retained with a dusty surface. The taste is a medium-high sweet and light bitter. It?s a chewy, full malty bodied beer, with a fizzy carbonation. Notes of candy, sweet cherry, oak, and cola come through. the finish is dry and astringent with a lingering, malty aftertaste.
Nice peaty scotch ale. Full bodied and flavored. Sweet and smokey. A little too carbonated, but thats just nitpicking. Dark fruit abounds as well. Nice brew...though steep in price."
A nice scotch ale. Pours a dark mahogany. Aromas are bread, dried fruit and caramel. Similar malty qualities. Good stuff.

Bottle cellared since 2010. Aroma of caramel and bourbon vanilla. Appearance is a clear ultra dark reddish brown. Taste is toasted caramel, bourbon, some vanilla. Sweet yet pretty good considering its age.

Bottle thanks to Tim and Rachel! Deep murky brown pour with a small tan head. Nose is full of toasted bread, toffee, caramel, dark fruits and earthiness. Flavor is similar with a low carbonation and balanced thick body. Pretty good with the age on it.

Pours a hazy copper from the bottle with thin filmy tan. head that sticks lightly. Aroma is heavy wood, toasted caramel, dark fruitiness, and a hint of booze. Taste follows, wood is mellowed by the intense sweet maltiness, lots of dark fruit and toffee that lingers. Good stuff.

Bottle @ Ben and Gregs apartment. 2009 Vintage from Dans basement. Pours a dark orangish brown appearance with a thin tan head. Somewhat oxidized, kind of smoky, caramel, burnt aroma. Toffee, brown sugar, meaty smoky, light oxidized flavor. I was expecting the worst but this isnt bad at all.
Big, sweet, carmelly beer.  Pours brown with good head.  Big malt, slight roast, good full finish without being heavy.  I think its good for the style, just not my favorite category.

Location/Date:Bottle on January 26th, 2013 during day 2 of Nerd Beer Epic Weekend.
Appearance: Pours a dark maroon. 
Aroma: Aroma of light caramel. 
Taste: Caramel malt, faint hop, faint smoke.   
Palate:Medium light body
Summary: Thanks Ben for bringing this one! Really enjoyed it, nice balance.
1 liter brown swingtop bottle. Dense brown with white head. Smokey malty aroma. Full body with big malty flavor. Slightly sweet flavor balance. Nice.
(bottle - 2009 release) deep brown, hints of red, light brown head. Aroma of sweet malt, some dark fruit. Flavor is sweet roast malt, caramel, some smoke.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown body with ruby-hued edges underneath a small, beige head thats rather on the sudsy side.

Smell: A grainy edge atop sweetish caramel, figs, and, oddly enough, a hint of orange peel. Moistened cardboard and spirits round out the Sheep Eater.

Taste: A similar grainy start to the taste, some caramel brushed toast slices, and that papery, oxidized element jumping right in. Lightly fruity. Some alcohol hints, seemingly more than one would expect given the listed ABV percentage. Faint spiciness, some curious woodsy tones, and a smidgen of peat. All these things are butting their heads, disjointedly vying for your attention in finish. It culminates into just an odd taste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-low carbonation.

Overall: Hes dead, Jim.

Date: June 26, 2011
Mode: Bottle
Source: Rare Beer Club
Appearance: clear dark ruby red, streaks of drippy lace
Aroma: rich sweet malt aroma, dark caramel sweetness, touch of candy
Flavor: rich dark caramel flavor, touch of peaty smokeyness
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

Aged 2009 pours crimson brown with one finger beige head. Aroma is sweet and fruity, raspberry and malt. Taste its immaculate cold. Sweet and very smooth. Creamy with a reserved graininess, light raspberry and cherry sweet flavor with cocoa and some vanilla. Roasted finish is still slightly sweet, alcohol shows as it warms and grain becomes less smooth. This its immediately satisfying, it is a really good beer aged 2 years.

1 liter swingtop bottle courtesy of phaleslu. Thanks! 209 vintage bottled 12/17/09. Pours a clear brownish ruby color with a large tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aromaof toffee, raisin, toasty notes, earthy notes. Maybe a little oxidized. The taste is toffee, earthy notes, cherries, raisins. Medium-full bodied. Nice beer.

Appearance:  medium-dark brown with rusty highlights; short, fizzy off-white head, minimal lacing.  Aroma: sweet and malty caramel, with good notes of black pepper, smoky red meat, leather, and sauna.   Taste:   malt-forward and sweet, but not overly so; peat-smoked malts come through, bringing whisky notes and a good dose of jerky; also notes of chocolate, oak and leather.   Finish: smooth, slightly dry, definitely smoky, and with a pleasant, meaty low burn.   Notes: Very interesting beer.  Loved that even with all the malts and sweetish notes, it want nearly as overpoweringly sweet as the style can sometimes get.  The peat-smoked malt addition was genius; that touch alone imparted so much flavor and complexity.  Absolutely loved it, and am sad that Ill probably never have another.  Got it from Rare Beer Club; one liter bottle, 2009 vintage.

09 bottle from Rare Beer Club: pours cola brown with bubbly brown head that recedes to a frothy, permanent ring. Sticky lacing on the glass. Roasted malts, esters, molasses, dried dark fruits on the nose. Rich mouthfeel, biscuits, caramel, toffee malts on the tongue. Sticky on the lips. Well balanced and smooth with a medium finish. Tasty and drinkable

Poured from a 22oz flip top bottle into tulip glass.  Pours a beautiful chestnut color.  Aroma was peat, sweetness, smoked malts.  Taste was sweet, smokey, toffee, carmel.  An awesome example of this style.

2009 monster bottle.  Tasting notes are a few weeks old, so this will be short and sweet.

Tasted after having AleSmith Wee Heavy (3.7 rating).  CRAZY different, with enormous amounts of peat and smoke, actually resembling a bit of Caol Ila 12 single malt on steroids.  Lacks sweetness, opposed to the overly-sweet Wee Heavy.  7.5% ABV is not hidden well at all, this actually felt much MORE alcoholic.  Not bad, but a swift kick in the tail compared to other scotch ales!
Draft at Cambridge Commons.  Cloudy dark brown, beige edge head.  Aroma of bitter cocoa.  Taste of thick caramel syrup, toffee.  Sweet and rich.

1L bottle Michael Jacksons Rare Beer Club (January 2011) 2009 Vintage, 2/23/11


Aroma: The nose is fairly sweet, lots of rich caramel and roasted malts and some dark fruits

Appearance: A dark brownish color, slight red hue, and bubbly brown-beige head

Flavor: The taste is rich and malty, fairly complex, dark fruity flavors, roast, and a drop of smoke

Palate: This one has a medium-full body with a smooth and sticky feel, soft carbonation

Overall Impression: 
I can see why this one gets the acclaim that it gets.  It is rather good, and if I can say that after drinking a whole liter of it, so it must also be pretty darn drinkable.  Anyway, this is very solid.  One that I would and will drink again.  It is really high quality stuff.
Dark with carmel flavors, dried fruit. Bread brought out the earthy almost peat moss quality. Heavy malt flavor. Low carbonation. Had with a pork stew. Fuller body then other scotch ales I have had.

Bottle - 1L swing top for the Rare Beer Club. Vintage 2009. Dark, murky mahogany-ruby blend. Medium, frothy beige head. Aroma is pleasantly smoky/peaty with sweet malt, chewy caramel and light smoked meat notes. Taste is delicious! Sweet malt, more big caramel notes, smoke/peat, light wood, smoked meat and toasty notes. Light candy fruit as well. Body is medium with a chewy overall feel and a moderate, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more caramel, candy notes, peat/smoke, light wood, smoked meat and soft toffee. Rather enjoyable. Im kind of glad I have a 1L bottle now!

1L bottle from South Bay Drugs, purchased back when I was in Cincy and before I knew I could get GT stuff in St. Louis. 2009 vintage, brought it up to The Royale on their Tuesday Night Beer Showcase featuring the brews of Grand Teton. Pours a nice deep brown color with some reddish highlights and a finger-thick off-white head. Aroma of pistachios, brown sugar, caramel malts, figs, peat, and other mixed nuts. Flavor also had some nuts and pistachios in particular, along with caramel malts, brown sugar, earth, and plums. Medium-bodied, with a malty, earthy mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Really nice Scotch ale that I enjoyed more than I expected.

Pours a deep chestnut with a thin white head.  Mellow and peaty on the nose with significant brown sugar.  Smooth on the tongue with start of cola, pecan and molassas moving into a complex roasted malt.  Finishes with a burn of alcohol that complements the smooth start.

1 litre swingtop bottle.  Pours a deep brown with a moderate light brown head that lasted through the first two sips and left spotty lace.  Pleasant aroma of peat, malt, and brown sugar.  The flavor closely follows the aroma with peat, malt, and brown sugar.  There is a bit of caramel sweetness in the flavor as well.  Very mild bitterness at the finish.  Medium-full bodied with a rich mouthfeel.  Enjoyable.  As an aside, I wish Grand Teton made their labels easier to remove so these swingtops could be used more easily for homebrewing!

1.0 liter bottle. Bottled 2009. Served at cellar temperature.  Pours a short lived, light beige head, over a clear brown (SRM 20) body.....nose is molasses, toffee/caramel, dried fruit (raisin, plum, light cherry).....taste is sweet malts, with molasses and layers of dried fruits including raisin, cherry, light smoke on the finish, minimal hop bitterness.....mouth feel is thick and sticky, carbonation adds a light spritz. This meets the style quite well. It is thick, heavy, rich, sweet, reminiscent of Port and sweet Sherry.  The sweetness is too dominant. As a result, this is not the best in the style, but is a most credible effort. BJCP 7/3/14/4/7

Thanks to my brother for sharing this bottle. Bottled Dec. 17, 2009. 

The beer pours a dark brown color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the toffee and peat-smoked malt. There is a lot more smoke than I was expecting, but it smells nice. The flavor is smoke, caramel and toffee malt, chocolate malt and earthy hops. As the beer warms I get a lot more tobacco and leather components in the flavor. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

2009 cellar reserve. Pours reddish brown, with very little head. Aroma is slightly sweet. Taste is malty, with a very nice scotch ale flavor. Smooth, with good body, well balanced. Thumbs up, very nice!
Bottled.  Hazy mahogany colour, small head. Aroma of caramel and winegums. Sweet and fruity, full bodied. Malty with plenty of chocolate sauce and estery winegum. Fairly low bitterness.

Bottle. 2009 batch. Dark amber hue with a thin tan head. Nose is rich sweet bready malts with hints of caramel, peat, and smoke. Flavor is rich and delicious malts, peat moss and caramel up front followed by rich sweet breads, hints of wood and light alcohol warmth in the sweet finish. Full body, light carbonation, thick texture. A great aged scotch ale with complex flavorful malt profile.

1L bottle at the BevMo fest.  Pours a cloudy medium nutty brown color with a well-formed light tan head sitting on top.  The aroma is rather peaty and smoky, meaty almost, with caramel malts.  The flavor has a slightly sweet caramel base, nuts, peat-smoked malt, light toast, and mild hop bitterness.  Medium-full bodied and slightly syrupy yet smooth on the palate.  A solid scotch ale overall.  Not the best Ive tried, but definitely enjoyable.

Wow, what a surprise. This is by far the best of these Cellar Reserves and its not really close. Very flavorful, lot of heavy peat flavor, but sweet molasses also, like a barleywine. Sits great in the stomach. Other than the price this beer is truly fantastic.

Bottle This beer rocks! Clear, deep, dark, mahogany ale with a mid-sized, creamy, off-white head. Fantastic retention. The rich, malty nose is a decadent swirl of caramel and mocha. Mercifully hop-less with a whisper of campfire smoke. Full-bodied with an oily/velvety mouthfeel and modest carbonation. The flavor offers mocha and huge caramel. Leans way sweet, but minerally hops save the day. Finishes minerally and lightly bitter. Tastes so freaking good, as Jordan semi-insinuates, there could be artificial flavor in here. If there is, I dont give a flying fuck. If this beer were named "savory flavor #852-H" instead of Sheep Eater, Id still drink it. World class bottle of beer courtesy of growler

Bottle: Pours a dark mahogany with a tan head. The nose is rich and roasty, plenty of plum and sweet robust malts, very solid malty body with a creamy resin in the tail. Balanced bitterness and a smooth mouthfeel and flavor. Finishes creamy and malty, this is one damn fine scotch ale, maybe a bit more like a big brown ale, but its an umami filled melanoidin festival.

Pours deep mahogany into a thistle. Tight off-white head with good retention slowly recedes to skim surface. Dark fig, raisin and treacle aromas. Smooth and creamy with sweet mollasses and figs. Nice.

1 liter bottle  RBWG 2010.  Pours a deep brownish ruby with a medium off beige head.  Aroma is hints of smoked, burnt malt, ash, light peat note, brown malt, roast, earth, sugary sweet fruity esters, plum and raisin.  Flavor has toffee, molasses, burnt notes, slight smoke, big thick sticky malts, fruity esters, with some herbs and mint and finishes a slight bit thin for me.

Hazy brown-purplish color with thin rapidly disappearing foam. Sweet grape-juice malty aroma.  Chewy with bready, malty and peaty flavors and very little hopiness.   Tastes almost more like a double bock.

1 litre bottle. Dark maple brown with nice tan head. Aroma has raspberry and apple sauce fruity esters. rich and sweet malty overall, also wood and cookies. Taste is sweet with huge malt profile, deep caramels and gamey meat (duck), and maybe some dark berry fruits. Finish is sticky sweet boozy.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy/creamy, light brown, mostly lasting.
Body is medium to dark brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie, toasted grain), lightly hoppy (apricot), with notes of nut shells / sherry, alcohol, slightly rotting plums, overripe banana skin.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

Too syrupy sweet, and the aroma leaves a lot to be desired, although admittedly this is probably past its peak (for my tastes anyway, most people who like aged beer would probably dig it)...still on store shelves around here.

1L Bottle:  Aroma of lots of malt, burnt caramel, prune, fig, and light peat.  Poured very dark amber/brown in color with a small, creamy, very dense, tan head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Not sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Flavor is medium sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, burnt caramel, prune, ad light peat.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, burnt caramel, prune, and light peat finish.

Bottle:  Pours a stunning ruby color with a modest, creamy brown head.  Nose is delicate with earthy malts, wood, moss, and peat.  Dark fruits, caramel, and butterscotch.  The forefront of the taste is sweeter and has a light fruit tint, before the looming malty presence takes over.  Deep, earthy malts with a nice peat and smokey presence.  Some chocolate.  Toasted malts and woody.  It really lends blends well, but the flavors stand on their own too.  Truly a beautiful brew.

1L fliptop bottle - 

Aroma - there are times, albeit too far in between, when you get a beer and the aroma.  This was one of those times.  Beautiful caramel malts, strong peat notes, light butterscotch and leather chair.  Almost has a sweet incense like aroma to it.

Appearance - dark amber/copper body, murky like something out of a rusty can.  Creamy tan 1" thick head.  Filled my Duvel glass really nicely.

Taste - smokey toffeeish malts, prunes, scorched marshmallows with some burnt toast.  

Palate - smooth, full bodied, slightly sticky mouthfeel

Overall - another homerun from Grand Teton brewing, and while the price is a bit steep, its a high quality indulgence and worth every penny I thought. Would highly recommend.

Liter bottle shared by Tim, thanks man 
Appearance: Pours dark brown with a nice beige head and a good amount of lacing left in the glass 
Aroma: Toasted malts, dusty, woody 
Taste: Caramel, oak and smokey 
Very nice scotch ale, tasty

Big old liter bottle shared by Timbo, thanks man. Pours a murky beige color with a medium beige head. The aroma is huge malts, caramel. A sweet flavor of caramel, dusty malts, toasted flavors. Easy drinking and tasty.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2010 1 ltr bottle into dimpled mug, shared with Brenn79. Aroma of wood, sweet malt. Pours a deep reddish brown with a medium head that dissipates pretty quick. Nice creamy lace. Taste is sugary sweet with no bitterness. Theres more than a hint of smokiness. Medium carbonation, oily texture. Interesting.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2010 1.5 ltr bottle- Pours brownish black with a nice tan head and sticky lacing, aroma is brown sugar and malt. The flavor is better than expected, but should I expect anything less from this excellent brewery, brown sugar and caramel malts make for one hell of a brew.

Bottle shared by one of dakines friends -- thanks.  Pours a syrupy dark amber hue with a fleeting khaki head.  Smells and tastes of candy sugar, barley, sweet malts, faint cherries, and smoke.  Nice for the style.

Pours deep reddish brown with off white head, aroma is big peat, sweet malt with some brown sugar and roasted malt.  Taste is campfire and peat up front, leading into caramel and sugar sweetness finishing roasted.  Fairly good, couldnt drink a ton of this but very interesting brew.

bottled jan 27, 2010 via az wine company on 5/18/2010. 

hazy dark brown... cola colored with a small off white head.

the nose is immediately peaty... along with tons of malty sweetness, brown sugar, warm spices and a slight boozy tingle.

the palate is sweeter than id ideally care for (certainly not so for the style) which gives the mouth feel some heft. it is smooth across the tongue and a touch creamy. flavors of earthy peat, light smoke, malt and nearly burnt brown sugar dominate. there is a bit of bitterness on the finish akin to burnt sugar as well. 

not bad, but id have to fight to take this bottle down myself. 7/4/7/3/15/3.6
Dark burnt Carmel color. Malty earthy nose. Very rich Carmel, earth, must flavors. Clean bitter finish. Dang yummy.
Brown color with a small head. Aroma is malty sweet with a hint of earthyness and smoke. Flavor is sweet and malty, more than aroma. Some grain and cardboard.
Poured dark reddish brown, caramel malts, toffee, smoke, dark fruits, little bready.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Tap. Murky brown pour with a thin off-white head. Aroma of peat, malt, and toffee. Creamy and medium bodied. Taste is caramel, malt, and smoke. Pretty good.

1ltr swing top. Rating #28. Very murky dark brown pour with a light tan head. Lightly toasted and a bit of caramel as well and a bit fruity. Rich and malty, some caramel sweetness and really tasty overall, good stuff. (1194)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Murky caramel pour with a thin tan head.  Aroma is toffee, malt, and butterscotch.  Flavor is less than mind-blowing but smooth.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Not bad.

nice dirty brown pour with good head and nice spotting, smoke and peat come through nicely in the aroma, and even more so in the flavor. nice full body, some creaminess, smooth finish and aftertaste. nice drinkable beer, not outstanding really, but not offensive in any way.  nice bourbony aftertaste, good compromise.

Pours a deep brown/slight red, with short tan head. Aromas of caramel, toffee, smoke, slight cherry. Rich malty, smoky flavor. Starts sweet, quickly followed with just enough alcohol heat. Has a nice malty thickness. Could benefit from a slight increase in carbonation.
Deep copper/amber pour with light tan head and lace. Caramel, toffee, and peat on the aroma. Sweet dried fruit flavor, peaty, and a hint of abv. Full bodied with good carbonation.

Bottle thanks to Jacob Cox.  Now we have to get you to join ratebeer! Pours a brownish color.  Nice sized head.  Aroma has some smoked malt, caramel, toffee, spice cake, molasses, prunes and yeasty hints.  Flavor is full and very nice.  Hints of smoke, toffee, fruit, caramel, light chocolate.  Very good beer.  Would love to try this one on tap.

Pours a deep red-brown with a nice beige head and some lacing. Aroma-raisins, candied plums, sweet malt, earth, alcohol, smoky. Taste- sweet, malty, smoky, molasses, very complex. Smokiness is most obvious at first, then backs off a bit and adds another dimension to the sweet malty foundation, providing a smoky undertone. Slight hop bite in the finish. Full bodied. Really well done.

Bottle.  Pours a mahogany body with an off white head.  Deep woody adn caramel malt tones.  Light ash with toffee and some bitter earth notes.  Light peat and caramel with a modest meat y warming.  Nice.

1 litre swing top bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of carmel, peat smoke, toffee and light fruittiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of toffee, peat smoke, carmel, dates and figs with a smooth lingering peaty malty finish.

Swing-top bottle from Total Wines. Pours dark brown with a decent tan head and a smoked malt aroma. There is a rich dark malt flavor that is, indeed, peat infused. The brewer has truly accomplished the objective of highlighting the malt. This would be an outstanding beer if it were not for a slightly annoying herbal off-taste. At any rate, an enjoyable brew.

From a one liter swing-top bottle purchased from Pauls Market in McCall, Idaho this  7.5% ABV brew pours a dark brown with a big bubbled head and moderate lacing. The nose is malty with notes of peat,  The body is fairly full and  the mouthfeel is rich and smooth.  The flavor is smokey malts with a distinct burnt taste.  As we move toward the finish there is a  tiny bit of hop bitterness , but mostly it is malty and smokey.  Front start to finish there is an alcoholic presence.
(1L bottle)  Pours a deep amber body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of peat, caramel, raisins, some cherry, and brown sugar.  Flavor of caramel malt, earth, and peat.

Really really good beer! If you really crave a big malty beer, you got to try this. Quality and quality. Very thick and almost syrupy mouth feel. The aroma is out of this world! Strong maple syrup essence. Malt heaven. Super smooth. Smoky. You can really taste the peat smoke. An interesting background sweetness weaves in and out through out the tasting experience. And I do mean EXPERIENCE! A malt bomb. Delicious!

Sampled on 3/26/2010. This scotch ale pours a deep amber brown color from a 1L swing top bottle. Medium sized beige foamy head, with decent lacing and nice retention. The aroma is smoky malts, brown sugar, bready, fruity and sweet.  A medium to full bodied Scotch Ale. The malts are caramel, bready and sweet, slightly smoky and peaty. The hops are earthy. Nice balance. Very smooth taste. Nice sipping beer. Another one of the very good/outstanding Cellar Reserve Series from Grand Teton. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
RBWG 2010. Pours reddish brown color with off white head. Aroma of peat smoked malts. Malty flavor with some peat smokiness. Medium body with average carbonation.
this one has a nice smoky kick to it that plays well with the roasty malt profile.  even detecting a little bit of hops here too.  a little warming too.

Aroma is medium/dark malt-peat.  Taste is medium/dark malt-peat, toffee, secondary earthy hops.  Medium/full body.
1L bottle, RBWG.  Medium tan head atop clear copper body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, prune/raisin.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, raisin, some molasses.  Sticky medium-full body.

2009 vintage (bottled 12/17/09) bottle. Pours with a hazy ruby body (thick pour) and a creamy tan head. Aroma of stones, minerals, peat, fig, caramel and smoke. Taste is smokey, big sweet, caramel and dark fruits. Light bubbles and creamy. Not too drinkable at all. Not my favorite Scotch Ale, not by a long shot.
Black with a creamy tan head.  Chocolate, caramel, and vanilla aroma and taste with a nice buttery palate.  Pretty good.
Bottle. Dark toffee colored beer with a cream colored head. caramel and toffee aroma. Toffee and light vanilla flavor with light backing fruit. Medium-plus bodied. Toffee and light vanilla linger.

From tap at Monks Kettle. Pours dark brown with a deep amber glare. Huge creamy and tan head. Aroma is caramelish and mild roasted. Smoked and dark roasted to chocolate malty. Bitter and dark roasted finish. Sweet dark caramelish lasting impression. Nice and bitter finish.

1L swingtop from Bevmo in Pleasant Hill, Ca. 7.5% ABV.  Pours a rather opaque brown with some coarse tan bubbles on top. Smells peaty and darkly roasted malty. Its rather full bodied with coarse carbonation. The flavor is peaty/smokey malt - quite sweet - but its acceptable. There might be a little hop bitter, but not enough to quell the malt beast. It finishes vry smooth, malty, smokey and delicious. The mouth feel is luscious.

1L swing tab bottle pours black with a small, creamy, khaki head into a snifter; nice lacing.  The head disappears quickly.  This has one hell of a malty aroma; also fresh biscuits, vanilla, peat.  Very malty profile, zero hop flavor.  Quite peaty with some roastiness, slight vanilla/dark caramel-like sweetness.  Silky mouthfeel with low carbonation and full body.  Quite drinkable and goes down very smoothly.  This is malt juice, and I absolutely love it.

1/30/10 notes: bottle, sample.  Pours murky light brown with not much head to speak of.  Aroma rich of caramel, toffee, earthy, peat.  Flavor is sweet but nuanced, a solid blend of bready, caramelly, lightly toasted flavors.  A very attractive version of this style, one of GTs best.
Pours dark brown with a thin beige head. Aroma of sweet malt and a hint of smoke. Flavor is rich and malty, peaty smoke, with a lightly bitter finish.

NUMBER ONE WHOOOOO~! * Trademark Natureboy Ric Flair.

Appearance: Pours a rootbeer brown with almost no head but rather a gathering of frothy swirlls.

Aroma: Vanilla, alcohol and smoked peat.

Taste: Smokey peat, roasty malt and bitter Euro hops.

Mouthfeel: Thin with low carbonation.

Overall: Super flavorful, smokey and spicy.
